thread.title: Taking the Slow Boat (and Train) From London to Paris
thread.title_full: Taking the Slow Boat (and Train) From London to Paris - The New York Times

author: Masha Goncharova
title: Taking the Slow Boat (and Train) From London to Paris
text:
For travelers weary of the oft-crowded Eurostar, the high-speed train from London ’s St. Pancras station to Paris ’s Gare du Nord, there is a breezier and greener route. It consists of two trains and a ferry, a bit of British and French culture, and tasty stops along the way.
The journey is about seven hours longer, but in addition to avoiding an onslaught of business travelers and tourists, it will take you through some of the most scenic parts of southern Britain and northern France.
Brittany Ferries is the most popular company, offering trips from Portsmouth, England, to Le Havre, France, that take about four hours. Add the cost of train rides from London to the ferry, and from the ferry to Paris, and the total cost of this extended trip rounds out to about $130 — roughly the equivalent of the least expensive Eurostar ticket (£80, or about $122).
